article.headline: McCants ties UNC record with eight 3s
article.linkText: UNC improves to 50-0 at home vs. Clemson
article.story: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. (AP) -- Last month, Clemson upset North Carolina with a barrage of 3-point shots. Rashad McCants returned the favor Tuesday night. The sophomore scored 30 points and tied a school record with eight 3s to lift the No. 14 Tar Heels past Clemson 69-53. McCants added two steals and was one point shy of matching his career high for the Tar Heels (18-8, 8-7 Atlantic Coast Conference), who improved to 50-0 all-time at home against the Tigers. Sean May added 17 points, seven rebounds, three steals and two blocks. North Carolina's home streak against Clemson is the second-longest in NCAA history. Princeton won 52 straight home games against Brown from 1929-2002, setting the record for consecutive home wins against one opponent. Clemson (10-17, 3-13) won the first meeting 81-72, shooting 56 percent and going 11-for-13 from 3-point range. On Tuesday, the Tigers watched as McCants hit 8 of 13 3-pointers, adding to a collection of top-flight performances that include key 3s in wins against Connecticut, North Carolina State and Maryland. McCants came in averaging 22 points and shooting 54 percent in his last 12 games, and continued his recent strong play. After scoring 22 points and hitting two key 3s in Sunday's win against N.C. State, McCants went 11-for-19 from the floor, routinely finding openings along the perimeter. He spotted up with the confidence that the outcome was certain. "I think anybody who can really shoot thinks that way," McCants said. "I'm just feeling anybody who's in front of me really can't stop me from doing what I need to do." McCants scored 14 points and went 4-for-5 behind the arc in the first half, sparking a struggling North Carolina offense that shot just 36 percent before the break. He scored 11 points in a 15-1 first-half run that gave the Tar Heels the lead. He hit three 3s in the spurt, including one from NBA range on the right side just before the horn for a 26-18 lead at the break. He matched the school record with a 3 from the right wing, giving the Tar Heels a 53-41 lead and bringing the Smith Center crowd to its feet with 8:12 to play. McCants found space so easily against the Tigers' physical man defense that Clemson coach Oliver Purnell yelled to his team "Quit leaving McCants open!" during a timeout with 6:59 left. "Every time we made a run, there was McCants breaking that momentum with a big shot," Purnell said after the game. North Carolina coach Roy Williams said he ran two plays late for McCants to break the record, but McCants missed both 3s and left the game with 50 seconds left. Williams said McCants was "sensational." "I love kids who step up and challenges, and he's stepped up at crunch time in several games this year," Williams said. "He's been willing to take the shot and he's made the most of them." McCants was the only Tar Heels player to find much rhythm against Clemson's physical man defense. The rest of the Tar Heels combined to shoot 17-for-45. North Carolina shot 44 percent, and hit 11 of 23 3-pointers to keep the home win streak alive. "We don't have anything to do with what happened in the past," May said, "but like I told everybody else, we needed to win this game for the guys who played here before us. "It's something that means a lot to the former players and we don't want to be the team to let that streak die." Clemson, meanwhile, had more turnovers (23) than field goals (21), and shot 43 percent. Sharrod Ford scored 14 to lead the Tigers, who will enter next week's ACC tournament as the No. 9 seed. The Tar Heels were short-handed for the second straight game, playing without top reserve Jackie Manuel, who sprained his right ankle in practice Friday and missed the N.C. State game.
